properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: First heat event of the year today. Daytime high temperatures are expected to reach 30 degrees Celsius today with humidex values near 35. Cooler air will move in for Wednesday as Tropical Depression Cristobal approaches. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-06-09T23:54:38-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-06-09T07:55:38-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2081174849.2020
Area: Sault Ste. Marie - St. Joseph Island
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Heavy downpours giving local rainfall amounts of 25 to 50 mm by mid afternoon. Showers and a few embedded thunderstorms will continue to soak the area today. Rainfall amounts of 25 to 50 mm are likely across much of the region by mid afternoon. Motorists should be prepared for ponding of water on poorly drained sections of highways and other roads. Visibility may also be suddenly reduced to 500 metres at times in very heavy downpours. The ground may have less of an ability to absorb this rainfall due to rainfall over the past two days. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-06-09T21:59:09-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-06-09T14:51:09-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.4209675320.2020
Area: Sioux Lookout - Eastern Lac Seul, Kenora - Grassy Narrows - Whitedog, Sioux Narrows - Nestor Falls - Morson

properties.Title: Frost Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Frost may damage some crops in frost-prone areas. Minimum temperatures: plus 3. Location: Prince Edward Island. Time span: early Wednesday morning. Remarks: Patchy frost is expected to form tonight as clearing skies and light winds coincide with cool temperatures. ### Frost advisories are issued when temperatures are expected to reach the freezing mark during the growing season, leading to potential damage and destruction to plants and crops. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to PEstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #PEStorm.

properties.Title: Heat Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Heat event today through Wednesday. Temperatures today and Wednesday will easily reach 30 to 34 C across Southern Ontario as a hot and humid tropical air mass moves in. Overnight temperatures will remain in the low twenties, especially in urban areas tonight, providing little relief from the heat. Humidex values will reach the mid thirties this afternoon, then the upper thirties to near 40 on Wednesday afternoon. Hot and humid air can also bring deteriorating air quality and can result in the Air Quality Health Index to approach the high risk category. A cold front accompanied by showers and thunderstorms will move through Southern Ontario Wednesday night, bringing this heat event to an end. ### Extreme heat affects everyone. The risks are greater for young children, pregnant women, older adults, people with chronic illnesses and people working or exercising outdoors. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-06-10T08:15:12-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-06-09T16:16:12-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3834595266.2020

properties.Title: Heat Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: First heat event of the year today through Wednesday. Temperatures today and Wednesday will easily reach 30 or 31 C across the region as a hot and humid tropical air mass moves in. Overnight temperatures will remain near 20, providing little relief from the heat. Humidex values will reach the mid to upper thirties on Wednesday afternoon. Hot and humid air can also bring deteriorating air quality and can result in the Air Quality Health Index to approach the high risk category. A cold front accompanied by showers and thunderstorms will move through Southern Ontario Wednesday night, bringing this heat event to an end. ### Extreme heat affects everyone. The risks are greater for young children, pregnant women, older adults, people with chronic illnesses and people working or exercising outdoors. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Severe Thunderstorm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Conditions are favourable for the development of severe thunderstorms that may be capable of producing strong wind gusts, large hail and heavy rain. Thunderstorms are developing in east central Alberta this afternoon and the potential exists for some thunderstorms to become severe. ### Large hail can damage property and cause injury. Intense lightning is likely with any thunderstorm that develops. Severe thunderstorm watches are issued when atmospheric conditions are favourable for the development of thunderstorms that could produce one or more of the following: large hail, damaging winds, torrential rainfall. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.
Expires: 2020-06-10T05:12:38-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-06-09T18:14:38-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1588813550.2020

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, at times heavy, is expected. Several thunderstorms in a row will continue to soak the area this morning with local rainfall amounts of 50 to 100 mm expected by mid afternoon. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
